analyzeResult.content:
Environmental control of allergens
JACQUELYNNE P. COREY, MO. Chicago, Illinois
Allergy therapy properly consists of three possible treatment methods that can be used singly or in combination: environmental control (avoidance), pharmacotherapy, and im- munotherapy. What allergens are effectively treated by environmental control? There are several broad groups of allergens with which we are concerned: Indoor allergens such as dust, animal dander, molds (indoor), and cockroach; and outdoor allergens such as trees, grasses, weeds, and molds (outdoor); and, lastty, foods. The largest body of work has been collected regarding the effectiveness of indoor allergens, especially dust mites and cat. Scientifically proven measures exist for dust mites, cats, and infant formulas. Practical advice for controlling the environment for other furred animals, cockroaches, molds, and pollens are summarized. More research on effective avoidance measures for these other allergens is needed to help our patients control their environment effectively. (OTOLARYNGOL HEAD NECK SURG 1994:111: 340-21
Allergy therapy properly consists of three possible treatment methods that can be used singly or in combination: environmental control (avoidance), pharmacotherapy, and immunotherapy. Many books and journal articles have been written about the latter two topics; few scientific data are available on the effectiveness and practicality of avoidance as sound medical advice. An easy prescription for the physician to give is. "If it hurts when you do that (pet a cat). don't do that (pet a cat)." The advice, how- ever, is often resented or ignored by patients. How then can we counsel patients to follow practical advice regarding avoidance of allergens? And what scientific evidence is there to back up the soundness of the advice we do give? What allergens are effectively treated by environmental control? This article will attempt to answer some of these ques- tions.
There are three broad groups of allergens with which we are concerned: indoor allergens like dust, animal dander, indoor molds, and cockroach; out- door allergens like trees, grasses, weeds, and out- door molds; and foods. The largest body of work has been collected regarding indoor allergens, especially dust mites and cat. Epidemiologically, control of
dust mites is especially important because of their role in exacerbating urban asthma.'
Although house dust has been known to be aller- genic since the 1920s, not until 1967 was the etiologic agent identified as house dust mite .? Dermatopha- goides pteronyssinus was the first dust mite identified as allergenic to human beings. Samples of house dust were found to contain large numbers of D. pteronyssinus; skin reactions to extracts of the mite were quantitatively and qualitatively indistin- guishable from those obtained with house dust ex- tract.' The major allergen (Der p I) has been purified by radioimmunoassay.' Most of the allergen is con- centrated in fecal particles 10 to 40 um in diameter.+ During natural exposure, both bed and floor dust samples have high concentrations of antigen that become airborne with domestic activity. Other sources include clothing and soft toys. The amount of allergen inhaled in natural exposure is low, but the inhaled particles are very concentrated in terms of allergen content.'
Dust mites prefer humidity level and tempera- tures similar to those preferred by human beings - humidity of 7 to 8 gm water per kilogram dry air and temperatures between 70° and 80º F. They feed on human scales and are thus abundant in human dwellings during most of the year when the heat is on. Other important species include Dermatopha- goides farinae (United States) and Euroglyphus may- nei (Europe).6.' D. farinae is found in stored food and on human skin.
What measures are available to control the envi- ronment for dust mites? Five methods are available: elimination of mite reservoirs, control of humidity,
From the Department of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Sur- gery, University of Chicago Medical Center.
Reprint requests: Jacquelynne P. Corey, MD, Otolaryngology- Head and Neck Surgery, University of Chicago Medical Center. 5841 S. Maryland Ave., MC 1035, Chicago, IL 60637.
